title: Metal−Organic Frameworks Provide Large Negative Thermal Expansion Behavior
abstract: Using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, we show that metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) constructed using octahedral Zn

clusters linked via aromatic carbon ring structures lead to negative thermal expansion (NTE) behavior (from 0 K to melting). We find that MOF-C22 contracts volumetrically by 1.9% over the range of 0 to 600 K, making it one of the best NTE materials (linear expansion coefficient of α = −11.05 × 10

previously the champion NTE material). Indeed, we designed a new MOF using 2-butynediodate linkers that leads to an even larger NTE of 2.2% (from 0 to 500 K). We show that this NTE behavior arises because thermal motions in the rigid Zn−O clusters and the organic moieties linking them lead to tilting of the linkers by successively larger amounts from their alignment along the unit cell axes, resulting in decreased cell parameters. The MOF materials were developed to provide a large reversible hydrogen-storage capacity leading to as much as 73% free volume. However, the NTE properties suggest other possible applications. Thus, their porous but constrained three-dimensional framework provides a framework onto which other materials might blend to form composites with negligible volume change with temperature. To illustrate this, we incorporated polyethylene polymers into MOF-C10 and found that the volume of the composite is constant within 0.059% over the entire range from 300 to 600 K.

We consider here a second class, the recent discovered metal−organic framework (MOF-5) materials consisting of Zn
(BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate). Experimentally, MOF-5 exhibits NTE behavior, with an observed increase in unit cell volumes of 1% upon decreasing the temperature from 293 to 30 K.
The MOF systems are promising candidates for storage and separation of gases because of its large surface area and low density.
Consequently, we decided to determine the mechanism for NTE behavior in MOF systems.

Here we report molecular dynamics (MD) simulations for five MOF systems, all of which exhibit NTE behavior. These calculations show that the NTE behavior originates from the increasing amplitude with temperature in the rotations of the rigid Zn−O clusters and the concomitant increased tilting of the organic linkers successively farther from their alignment along the unit cell axes.

On the basis of this interpretation, we designed a new MOF system predicted to have a particularly large NTE effect. In addition, we demonstrated an application of these NTE properties by developing a composite with nearly zero thermal expansion.

the mode-dependent Grüneisen parameter (γ = −∂ ln ω/∂ ln

) is a measure of the sensitivity of the phonon frequencies ω to changes in the system volume. Whether a solid expands or contracts upon heating depends on the balance between phonon modes with positive and negative Grüneisen parameters. For longitudinal acoustic and optical phonons, γ is typically positive so that these modes tend to promote thermal expansion. This results from anharmonicity in the bonding potentials, which leads to increased average bond lengths with increasing temperature.
In contrast, transverse vibrations may exhibit a negative γ related to the increase of the restoring forces with increased tension.

We find that the NTE behavior of MOF originates from transverse tilting of the organic linkers in the MOF because of rotational motions in the inorganic couplers. The MOF materials provide the possibility of manipulating the NTE coefficient by the choice of the organic linkers, which already allow a linear NTE coefficient of up to −11.01 × 10
The mechanism of NTE derived for the MOF compounds (Figure 3) is analogous to that of the Prussian blue family (M
, M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Cd), which contain linear diatomic cyanide anion bridges.

In the Prussian blue materials, the increase in average transverse displacement of the bridging atoms, through thermal population of low-energy transverse vibrational modes, is generally considered to induce the observed contraction of lattice parameters. The NTE behavior of the Prussian blue analogues varies widely with types of metal from near zero thermal expansion in NiPt(CN)
) up to a maximum in CdPt(CN)

The MOF systems have cubic crystal structures similar to the Prussian blues but with negligible expansion of the nearest-neighbor distances (based on the RDF analysis), but with MOF we have considerable flexibility in designing the linker to achieve larger NTE than for the Prussian blue analogues. Thus, the NTE behavior of MOFs can be modified both by the type of organic linkers (as considered here) and by replacing the Zn cluster in the nodes.

In summary, we use MD simulation to show that the cubic crystalline MOFs (IRMOF types) with Zn−O−C clusters and aromatic carbon rings can have unusually large negative thermal expansion (NTE) properties. This NTE behavior results from increased rotations with temperature of the rigid metal oxide polyhedral couplers with concomitant tilting in the organic linkers. This behavior leads to a soft material with low elastic constants. We show that the magnitude of the NTE effect is sensitive to the specific types of organic linker used. We also show that the NTE property of MOF can provide the basis for applications to composites, leading, for example, to composites with no volumetric change with temperature.

A review.  There has been substantial renewed interest in neg. thermal expansion following the discovery that cubic ZrW2O8 contracts over a temp. range in excess of 1000 K.  Substances of many different kinds show neg. thermal expansion, esp. at low temps.  In this article we review the underlying thermodn., emphasizing the roles of thermal stress and elasticity.  We also discuss vibrational and non-vibrational mechanisms operating on the at. scale that are responsible for neg. expansion, both isotropic and anisotropic, in a wide range of materials.

Isostructural ZrW2O8 and HfW2O8 show strong neg. thermal expansion from 0.3 K up to their decompn. temps. of ∼1050 K.  This behavior is esp. unusual because these compds. are apparently cubic over their entire existence range.  Detailed structural studies of ZrW2O8 were conducted using high-resoln. neutron powder diffraction data taken at 14 temps. from 0.3 to 693 K.  Below 428 K, ZrW2O8 adopts the acentric space group P213 and has a well-ordered structure contg. corner-sharing ZrO6 octahedra and two crystallog. distinct WO4 tetrahedra.  Above the phase transition at 428 K, which appears to be 2nd order, the space group becomes centric Pa‾3.  The structure is now disordered, with only one crystallog. distinct site for W.  One O site is 50% occupied, suggesting the possibility of high O mobility.  O motion at >428 K is also suggested by dielec. and a.c. impedance measurements.  The neg. thermal expansion of ZrW2O8 and HfW2O8 is related to transverse thermal vibrations of bridging O atoms.  These lead to coupled rotations of the essentially rigid polyhedral building blocks of the structure.  A semiquant. model for both the neg. thermal expansion and phase transition of these materials is proposed in light of the diffraction results.

The structure of 2H CuScO2 was refined from single-crystal x-ray diffraction data obtained at room temp. and from neutron powder diffraction data obtained from 11 to 1206 K.  Crystallog. data are given.  Strong neg. thermal expansion (-4.0 × 10-6/K) was found for the apparent Cu-O bond length <300 K.  This is the 1st example of strong neg. thermal expansion in a metal oxide based on an O-M-O linkage instead of a M-O-M linkage.  It is now the transverse thermal motion of Cu, instead of the transverse thermal motion of O, that causes the neg. thermal expansion.  As expected for this mechanism for neg. thermal expansion, the thermal displacement parameter for Cu is very pronounced perpendicular to the linear O-Cu-O linkage.

The primary adsorption sites for Ar and N2 within metal-org. framework-5, a cubic structure composed of Zn4O(CO2)6 units and phenylene links defining large pores 12 and 15 angstroms in diam., have been identified by single-crystal x-ray diffraction.  Refinement of data collected between 293 and 30 K revealed a total of eight symmetry-independent adsorption sites.  Five of these are sites on the zinc oxide unit and the org. link; the remaining three sites form a second layer in the pores.  The structural integrity and high symmetry of the framework are retained throughout, with negligible changes resulting from gas adsorption.
